bib.title: Excitation functions of alpha-induced nuclear reactions on natural erbium and natural ytterbium targets

free_txt: Prelim.data
CGR-560 cyclotron
KB
SD: Ref. on Nucl.Istr.&Meth. was added.
SD. Reference on Conf.Proc. was corrected.
SD: Entry deleted. Data were superseded by
entries: D4199, D4203
The measured experimental data were compared to
those found in the literature.
The measured experimental data were compared to
and analyzed with theoretical calculations based on
the model code ALICE-IPPE.
On the basis of the new experimental cross
sections and the results of the model calculations
integral yields were calculated and compared to
experimental yields taken from the literature.
Decay data were taken from WWW Table of Radioactive
Isotopes by Ekstrom and Firestone, database version:
The sample-detector distance was chosen carefully to
avoid pile-up effects and coincidence losses. The
detector efficiency was determined placing standard
sources at different distances from the detector.
The energy uncertainty of the beam at the
first foil is 0.3 MeV which increases along the stack
due to the energy straggling and the uncertainty of
target thicknesses and reaches 1.5 MeV at the last
foil.
The uncertainties of the cross sections were
determined in the standard way: the linearly
contributing independent processes were taken into
account extracting square root of quadratically summed
relative uncertainties, namely:
* number of the bombarding particles (7%),
* number of the target nuclei (3%),
* decay data (3%),
* detector efficiency (7%) and
* peak area (1-10%).
CGR-560 cyclotron
Two stacks of natural erbium and two stacks of natural
ytterbium target foils were irradiated, each
interlarded with Ti monitor foils. At the beginning of
one of the two stacks an Al degrader foil was placed
to ensure a small energy shift.
Incident alpha energies: 37.5, 37.9, 38.5 and 39.0 MeV,
beam currents: 119.5, 108.8, 136.9 and 127.6 nA,
irradiation times:  2.00, 2.58, 1.55 and 1.58 hours
in the case of the two erbium and two ytterbium stacks,
respectively.
No chemical separation.
The gamma spectra of the target foils were registered
by a PC-coupled HPGe detector system just after the
end of bombardment and again a month later to get
information for the radionuclei of short and long
half-life as well and to follow cumulative processes.
Chapter 4
The mean bombarding energy of the beam in the
subsequent foils was calculated following the
polynomial approximation for stopping power of
Andersen and Ziegler.
High purity foils, thicknesses:  Er 32., Yb 30.,
Al 25.5, Ti 12. micron.
